Posts.Content: At my recent one-year post surgery visit to the surgeon, the doctor noted only the small scar above my belly button was visible. The other small incisions from my Da Vinci surgery had faded. My 3+4 cancer seems to be gone too since my PSA remains undetectable. Yet, the whole experience does leave some invisible scars doctors can't readily see. A year out, you don't think about your prostate cancer quite as much as you do in the months around diagnosis and treatment, but there are reminders: peeing is as quick as when you were a kid now (a nice side effect!), rare occasional leakage occurs for me when lifting or running long distances, and worst of all, I was among a minority of guys who developed some Peyronies about six months after surgery. There are arguments about whether that developed as a result of using Trimix injections post-surgery (no longer using Trimix) or if something about prostatectomy surgery triggers Peyronies in guys who would've gotten it eventually. Either way, it is what it is. I'm glad to be alive and healthy. Something other than Prostate Cancer is probably going to have to do me in some day. My grandfather died of Prostate Cancer and my father in his late 70s is doing nicely treating his with hormone treatments after his prostate cancer surgery years ago. All in all, I feel pretty lucky a year after surgery!
Posts.Signature: BD: April 1958 March 2014 biopsy Gleason 3+4, 2/12 cores positive - 13% left base, 12% right base Pre-surgical PSA 4.91 May 2014: DaVinci surgery at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center Pathology report: pT2b. Gleason 3+4. July 2014: post-surgery PSA <0.05 (undetectable) November 2014: PSA <0.05 (undetectable) May 2015: PSA <0.05 (undetectable) April 2016: PSA <0.05 (undetectable)
Posts.Title: Looking back after one year

Posts.Content: As Paul Harvey used to say, "And now you know the rest of the story." I just got my PSA done again today --- this time at Memorial Sloan Kettering where I had done all my post-prostatectomy PSA tests until the one a couple of weeks ago that came out higher than undetectable .1 ng/mL. The good news is that MSKCC's lab shows my PSA is actually <.05 ng/mL and I remain in the zero club. My first mistake was changing labs. My primary care doc had me go to Quest Diagnostics to have my PSA tested along with other routine blood work. The second issue was my primary care doc ordered a Total PSA test, but (based on my subsequent investigation online) Quest Diagnostics evidently also offers at least a couple of high sensitivity PSA tests for post-prostatectomy folks, but that's not what my primary care doc ordered. The third issue is Quest Diagnostic's Total PSA results are not necessarily reported as <.1, when there should be a less than sign. (I found a discussion about inconsistency of Quest Diagnostics reporting Total PSA with a less than sign on another forum.) Important takeaways: always get your post-prostatectomy PSA tests from the same lab if you can, be sure it's the right version of PSA test, and watch out for possible omitted less than signs on reported results from certain labs. Whew!
Posts.Signature: BD: April 1958 March 2014 biopsy Gleason 3+4, 2/12 cores positive - 13% left base, 12% right base Pre-surgical PSA 4.91 May 2014: DaVinci surgery at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center Pathology report: pT2b. Gleason 3+4. July 2014: post-surgery PSA <0.05 (undetectable) November 2014: PSA <0.05 (undetectable) May 2015: PSA <0.05 (undetectable) April 2016: PSA <0.05 (undetectable)
Posts.Title: Is there a not quite zero club?

Posts.Content: Coming up on two years from my prostatectomy, and my PSA just came back greater than undetectable for the first time following surgery with a 0.1 ng/mL result. Below the 0.2 ng/mL point I understand is considered a biochemical recurrence, but still disappointing. Probably a good sign that it took two years to rise to 0.1. I suspect more frequent PSA tests are in my future. Ugh.

Posts.Title: Finally some good news

Posts.Content: After three weeks of wearing Depend Guards day and night since the catheter came out, I just walked a mile in my neighborhood without any pad and no leakage! Didn't think that would have been possible even a week ago. Everyone's experience is a little different, but the advice to buy just a package at a time and see how he recovers control seems wise.

Posts.Title: Best post surgery pads

Posts.Content: I agree with the others that it's best to get the biopsy done. I had mine in March. My urologist made a totally transparent effort to distract me with chit chat while he performed the biopsy core collection. It was uncomfortable but over quickly. I had a little cramping feeling afterwards for a couple of hours. BTW, if you don't have it, suggest you buy Dr. Patrick Walsh's book to really fill out your knowledge and allay unwarranted fears.

Posts.Title: is biopsy next best option

Posts.Content: Ralph, in addition to great forum input, you can take advantage of MSKCC's "My MSK" patient portal. I've gotten email responses very quickly from surgeon's staff to my post-op emailed questions --- sometimes in just a few minutes. BTW, you may want to ask your surgeon's staff to email your pathology report after they call with your results a few days after surgery because that's one thing they don't seem to include in your "My MSK" records section. Definitely something to have in writing! My bloating was really bad too, but mine was mostly gone three days after surgery and it made a big difference!

Posts.Content: Zak, in February, after years of careful monitoring showing my PSA creeping upward, my urologist said to me, "if we believe in the PSA it's time to do a biopsy." In March I did a biopsy. It was unpleasant but it was done in 8-10 minutes. My biopsy found Gleason 3+4 tumors. I was fortunate that timely surgery removed organ confined disease. Zak, ChemoMan's guidance is exactly right. You are not going to be able to dodge a biopsy before treatment. My advice: just buck up and do it if you suspect PC. It'll be over in 10 minutes, and the data you get can help you make a sound, science-based, medical decision.

Posts.Title: Current reading: Redefining Prostate Cancer. Overdiagnosed. The Great Prostate Hoax.

Posts.Content: I also experienced unusual urinary frequency in the period shortly after the catheter was removed. Just "go with the flow" and you'll probably find that your bladder starts to hold more as the days pass. I also experienced a fair bit of clotted blood in my urine on occasion in weeks immediately following catheter removal, so expect that possibility too.

Posts.Content: I'm one week post DaVinci surgery and am experiencing a small firm feeling lump immediately above the larger horizontal gland extraction site incision above my navel. Nothing like this at any of the port incisions. This firm lump has been present since right after the surgery. I'll see what my local urologist thinks when I go in Monday for catheter removal, but thought I'd check to see if others have experienced this following their robotic surgery.

Posts.Content: Fred, good luck resuming running. Unfortunately, unlike Chuck, I found that my six weeks of not running killed my conditioning and endurance. Starting again sucked. I'm now back up to 4.5 mile loops and my pace is still a little slower than before surgery which is fine by me. I'll be interested to know if you also experience leakage when you run. It's the only time I still need a pad.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon Hello Mark.....I guess I was one of the few who was diagnosed with PC without having any symptoms at all (Other than my PSA climbed). Since my Robotic Surgery in 2012, and then I had radiation treatment at the end of 2013 there has been no change at all in my urine flow. In preparation for the daily radiation session I had to have a full bladder and consumed at least 3L of water which I held for over 2 hours. When I did go to the bathroom it still came out like a fire hose (the urine I mean). B Brave: five days post surgery and it hurts a bit to laugh. The last sentence of your post, unfortunately, struck me as pretty funny.

Posts.Content: Welcome to the Prostate Cancer forum. I'm certain you will get lots of informed feedback from forum members who have been where you are --- me included. Our surgeries were five days apart. For me, I do find doing a lot of walking may be helping me make progress in control. I was hoping I would be one of those guys who were dry soon after the catheter came out, but for most of us it takes time.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ThatBiopsyHurt If I had a PSA of 118 and my urologist told me he couldn't do a biopsy for three weeks I would run, not walk, to another doctor. I think three days would be more reasonable. You need a biopsy now, not later, with that PSA. Ask for a referral to a colleague who can do it in the next few days if they won't squeeze you in sooner!

Posts.Title: symptoms then psa

Posts.Content: I had my 6 month post op appointment with my surgeon yesterday and my PSA came out less than 0.05 again. I remember reading posts here months ago suggesting that, after treatment, for some (maybe most) the cancer focus fades and life goes on --- perhaps explaining why some forum participants with excellent outcomes drift away. When I first read that, I couldn't imagine not thinking about my Prostate cancer all the time. Now, I find days go by without really giving it any thought. I still wear a pad just when I'm out running. ED is still a reminder, but Trimix is a reliable (hopefully interim) fix. All in all, a lot better than the outcomes from Prostate cancer that my dad and his dad experienced.

Posts.Title: The "Almost Zero Club" ?

Posts.Content: I didn't notice that earlier posters mentioned this about biopsies so I thought I'd add it to help prepare you: Immediately after your biopsy it is common to experience a bit of blood tinting the color of your urine but this clears up quickly. Also, it is normal for you to have blood in your ejaculate and that can be startling even if you've been warned. It clears up in a few weeks.

Posts.Content: Mikla, yes I have been alternating sides but just injecting at 10 and 2 o'clock as instructed by Dr. Mulhall's office. The little book is excellent. Wonder if I may be among the 3-8 percent mentioned in your book who develop Peyronies and the discomfort relates to that.

Posts.Title: Pain with erections

Posts.Content: Finally got into Sloan Kettering today. Multiple plaques identified by ultrasound today are causing the erection discomfort and new mild bend to starboard. Doc says mild pain with erections will disappear with time. Bend is there to stay. Current thinking, he says, is prostatectomy somehow accelerates appearance of plaques in men with genetic predisposition to develop Peyronies. Genetic predisposition is more common in men with Northern European ancestry. Can't say when it would've appeared in my case if I hadn't had Prostate surgery. Mine came six months after prostatectomy.

Posts.Content: I had Da Vinci surgery seven months ago. I have been having success using Viagra or Trimix injections, but beginning recently I've had mild pain in my penis during erections. Same pain occurs whether I inject or take Viagra to get the erection. Only get the pain with the erection. Have others experienced this?

Posts.Title: Pain with erections

Posts.Content: Hi Dave, As you consider your treatment options, while both radiation and surgery offer very good odds for a cure, it's worth reading up on the differing "salvage" treatment options/side effects you'd face if you someday experience a cancer recurrence. The book by Dr. Walsh that Chuck recommended previously covers this potentially important issue. It was a factor in my treatment decision.

Posts.Title: Recently Diagnosed with Questions

Posts.Content: My understanding is that urologists are typically guided by the core(s) reflecting the most mutated cells, so, for example, if any core was found to have Gleason 4 mutated cells that were more prevalent than the Gleason 3 cells in that core, urologists would say you have Gleason 7 disease with a 4+3. Other cores with lesser scores are notable, but treatment is guided by the high score finding. Remember, 12 cores still sample only a tiny fraction of your overall prostate tissue. Pick up a copy of Dr. Walsh's book. It's a great reference recommended frequently on this forum.
